speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Welcome to Contextualizing Feminist Voices, Teaching with the Global Feminisms Project.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: This series is focused on teaching, pedagogy, and uses of the archive in the context of

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: the classroom.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Designed with a special emphasis on educators, in each episode you will learn from

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: instructors who have used the project's interviews in their courses and about activities and resources

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: for incorporating the archive into your class. Today, Dr. Patrick Groszanka, Professor of

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: Psychology and Chair of the Interdisciplinary Program in Women, Gender, and Sexuality at the University of Tennessee, Knoxville,

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: joins us on the podcast. Dr. Groszanska's interdisciplinary work explores the complex

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: ways that social institutions such as healthcare, science, law, and education reproduce harm at the

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: intersections of race, gender, and sexuality. The second edition of his edited book, Intersectionality,

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: Foundations and Frontiers, was published by Rutledge in 2019, and his next book traces the

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: born-this-way wars, fierce debates about the origins of sexual orientation in science, law,

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: and the lives of sexual and gender minorities. He's active in various social movement organizations in Tennessee

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: and currently serves as a chair of the Board of Directors of Tennessee Advocates for Planet Parenthood.

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: Thank you so much for making the time to meet with us and provide your insights and your comments and your feedback on your classes.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: in my course, because I think it plays a really key role. So in my book, Intersectionality, which

text: attempts to introduce kind of advanced undergraduate students, early graduate,

text: for my students explores the concept of reproductive justice. So the framework,

text: the human rights framework, that is, that was developed by Black women in the U.S. in the 1990s

text: might say, sort of in the business, the single axis approach that they took a gender first or
